sub_title: Philosophy and Sociology of Public Health Maastricht University

projects.title: Citizens participation in health & care. Maastricht200 Citizens Summit (Burgertop)
projects.description:
www.maastricht200.nl

In 2014 en 2015 heb ik met honorsstudenten, en in samenwerking met de gemeente Maastricht, welzijnswerk, GGD en burgers een M200 georganiseerd, een burgertop waar burgers aan deelnamen op basis van loting uit de basis administratie. Een Burgertop is een democratisch experiment om in de context van de ''participatie maatschappij''  zorgen, oplossingen, ideeën en dromen van burgers over gezondheid en zorg in Maastricht te mobiliseren en nieuwe aanpakken uit te werken. Het proces rond de burgertop beoogt bij te dragen aan het verkleinen van de kloof tussen burgers en de politiek, het versterken van de lokale democratie en het vergroten van vertrouwen tussen burgers, experts en politiek. 
Voor verslagen zie www.maastricht200.nl

projects.title: Etnografisch actie-onderzoek sociale veiligheid, leefbaarheid en welzijn.
projects.description:
2015-2018
Actiegericht onderzoeken en ontwikkelen van lokale krachten en samenhang, en daarmee sociale veiligheid, leefbaarheid en welzijn in een A-wijk en een wijk met deels vergelijkbare problematiek gerelateerd aan de grensregio.
In opdracht van Provincie Limburg, gemeente Maastricht, gemeente Eijsden.

contributors.headline: Philosophy and Sociology of Public Health Maastricht University

projects.title: Masterclass Filosofie en praktijk van burgerschap en participatie in gezondheid en zorg
projects.description: Deze tweedaagse masterclass richt zich op de recente ontwikkelingen op het gebied van burgerschap en participatie in de (gezondheids)zorg. We gaan in op de opkomst van burgerschap en participatie, de betekenis van deze concepten, de veranderende verwachtingen ten aanzien van de overheid, en de verschillende manieren waarop  overheden daar op kunnen reageren. De dilemma’s van participatie en zelfsturing worden bediscussieerd aan de hand van praktijkvoorbeelden uit verschillende gemeenten. We reflecteren op de sociale technologieën die gebruikt worden om burgerschap en participatie op lokaal niveau vorm te geven, zoals de zelfredzaamheidsmatrix. Tevens besteden we aandacht aan nieuwe fenomenen zoals de burgertoppen, stadsgesprekken en burgerdialogen. Hoe gaan politici, beleidsmakers en praktijkprofessionals in de gezondheidszorg hiermee om en welke functies vervullen ze in de sociale en politieke arena? Tot slot staan we stil bij sociaaleconomische gezondheidsverschillen en sociaaleconomische participatieverschillen. Liggen deze in elkaars verlengde en hoe gaan we daar mee om?

contributors.headline: Philosophy and Sociology of Public Health Maastricht University

projects.title: Masterclass ''Philosophy of collaboration between science, policy and practice in Public Health''
projects.description: 20 en 21 maart 2013 gaf ik met Maria Jansen een Masterclass ''Filosofie van samenwerking in de publieke gezondheidszorg''. Het was de eerste keer dat we dit aanboden en er waren 20 deelenemers met zeer uiteenlopende achtergronden (GGD's, inspectie, onderzoekers, gemeente - chronische ziekten, jeugdzorg, gezondheidsbevordering, infectieziekten, ambulance zorg ). Mede dank zij hun gevarieerde inbreng waren het voor ons (en ook voor de deelnemers, zo bleek uit de evaluatie) leerzame dagen.    .

contributors.headline: Philosophy and Sociology of Public Health Maastricht University

projects.title: Exit and/or voice in the Dutch national vaccination program
projects.description: In several countries it becomes clear that vaccination programmes for children are less routinely accepted as in earlier decades. More and more citizens speak back and do not routinely follow professional and expert advice. Moreover, the classic categories of the vaccination refuters  - specific religious groups and people following the philosophical ideas of Rudolf Steiner - become blurred. These classic critical voices become mixed with several other kinds of criticism or distrust, not always resulting in a refusal to vaccinate but to questions about a more individualized vaccination scheme. In this project we study how in the Dutch national vaccination program of the RIVM voice and exit are  organized, how effectiveness sand public accountability are organized, and how in the future experts and citizens fruitfully can relate fruitfully in the context of these programs for infectious diseases control and prevention.

contributors.headline: Philosophy and Sociology of Public Health Maastricht University

projects.title: Signalling children at risk: following an ICT infrastructure in youth care from design to practice
projects.description:
In this PhD project we analyse the so-called ''implementation'''of an ICT system in the chain of youth care that aims to enable early detection of children-at-risk and to stimulate professional collaboration across organizations and disciplines. By doing fieldwork and interviews we try to understand the ''processes of implementation'' in different regions and municipalities of Brabant.

Thesis Inge Lecluijze, The wrong tool for the job. Maastricht, 4 November 2015

contributors.headline: Philosophy and Sociology of Public Health Maastricht University

contributors.name: Inge Lecluize, Bart Penders, Frans Feron

projects.title: Constructing genetics, family and kinship
projects.description: This project investigates how the development of a new genetic tests (for  a specific cardiovascular disorder) is related to the construction of family and kinship ties. A classic hypothesis states that genetics is re-making families in the era of individualization, others have pointed to the power of genetic to break families, as it might lead to conflicts and struggles. This study tries to provide more insight by choosing  a longitudinal design and by following families for a long period of time, interviewing them several times. To that purpose 6 extended families were followed intensively for several years.

contributors.headline: Philosophy and Sociology of Public Health Maastricht University

projects.title: Crossing boundaries, connecting cultures: evaluating a new social media approach in public mental health (Maastricht, Nairobi)
projects.description:
2012-2015 
This project aims to evaluate in a participatory-ethnographic way, a new social media approach for improving public mental health in communities that suffer from fragile mental resilience. The approach contains a local television soap as well as interactive web applications and local community work, employed in communities that do not trust  professional mental health institutions. This project aims to contribute to overcome the gap between high social economic class mental health professionals and lower social economic class communities, by a social media approach that is developed in interaction with the neighborhoods as well as mental health professionals and media professionals. The evaluation aims to provide insight in how the different cultures and idioms of ''mental health'' - more or less successfully - are becoming interconnected in this social media approach, and how this new approach affects ''mental health'' according to the different stakeholders involved.

contributors.headline: Philosophy and Sociology of Public Health Maastricht University

projects.title: Public legitimation of social health insurance in modern risk societies: input from anthropology and social studies of science
projects.description:
2013-2018
2 PhD's Payam Abrishami, Floortje Moes
In  2012 we developed a collaboration with the Netherlands Health Care Insurance Board (CVZ/Zorginstituut Nederland) to study public legitimation issues with respect to decisions about quality, package and professional education, to discuss these issues together to stimulate a public learning process about these issues. In the context of risings costs of health care, the introduction of preventive technologies, the reorganization of welfare states, political pluralism and public controversies about expertise, public legitimation of social health insurance is less socially robust as in the earlier decades. In this project we will investigate public legitimation issues in depth, making especially use of insights of science and technology studies.           
Two PhD's will work on this project 
Payam Abrishami  ‘Understanding the ‘real-life’ of health care technologies: anthropological input for decision-making' (started 1-1-2013)
Floortje Moes ‘Understanding the knowledge dynamics of decision-making within Dutch Health Care Institute’. (start 1-9-2013)

contributors.headline: Philosophy and Sociology of Public Health Maastricht University

projects.title: Research Program 'Philosophy and sociology of public health: on the interface of science, technology and society'
projects.description:
My research agenda ''Philosophy and sociology of public health'' deals with public health issues on the interface of science, technology and society. The research agenda is worked out in different concrete projects, that all depart from the idea that currently we face some rather paradoxical trends: on the one hand we live in a ''scientific and technological risk culture'', ''a culture of experts'', on the other hand we observe processes of democratization, democratization of expertise, and a growing importance of (mediated by new media) civil society. These processes of both rationalization and democratization create  problems of public legitimization, public trust and public accountability. This is the more the case as socio-economic and health differences between groups - in the Netherlands, in Europe and globally - do not decrease. It is an intriguing question whether and how problems of public legitimization and limited effectiveness of public health programmes might be connected. Public health demonstrates these problems more explicitly than other fields, as nation states organize public health ''for the population'' in top down strategies while taking science as an orientation point. However, more and more public health experiences that ''the public speaks back'', and so the question rises how ''the public'' is constructed, identified, enacted and enrolled. 
Against the background of these observations, the concrete projects contribute to getting insight in complex relationships between states or international bodies, experts, professionals and citizens/civil society/communities. To that purpose it critically studies the meaning of basic concepts like ''expert'', ''professional'', ''individual'', ''family'', ''evidence'', ''body'', ''citizenship'', ''risk''. It studies tensions between processes of standardization/localization, classification/diversification and tries to contribute to new  balances between 'science, technology and society
